Posts.Content: These symptoms could also be a sign of fluid retention, so I hope you have spoken with a physician or some sort of healthcare provider who is familiar with your medical history.
Posts.Title: Oestragen Blocker and consequenses

Posts.Content: Tykerb is only for a certain kind of breast cancer.  But women can live a long time with breast cancer metastases.  Treatment becomes like treating a chronic condition, like diabetes, for example.  It can be difficult but your mom should be the one who decides how much treatment she wants.  Incurable doesn't mean it can't be controlled and managed for a while.  She should get a second opinion and look at clinical trials as well.
Posts.Title: cancer reaccurence

Posts.Content: If you have radiation therapy to the breast area, the risk of scar tissue and hardening around the breast implant increases to 40–50%.  If the expander is still in make sure the port is plastic and not metal.  Sound like you do need to talk to a different plastic surgeon.  Quitting smoking was a good idea anyway.  Why treat one cancer while you are possibly giving yourself another?
Posts.Title: Needing advice or information.

Posts.Content: You need to get your pathology report and take a look at it.  It is fairly common these days to treat a large tumor with chemo first so that less surgery can be done.  It's irresponsible of a healthcare practitioner to tell you that your cancer must be aggressive because it's in a lymph node.  That's not always the case.  Breast cancer in premenopausal women can be more aggressive.  It may be in a node because the original tumor has been there long enough for it to have reached a node.  The path report will tell you how aggressive it is.  Hold off on the IV vitamin C--
Posts.Title: scared to death

Posts.Content: Talk to a genetic counselor first.  You may not need the testing.  We can only test for a few mutations right now--your family may have one that we don't have a test for.  Just the fact that you have a strong family history is telling you to be extra vigilant.  Generally it's ten years before the age the youngest person was diagnosed that you should start your mammos.  BUT it sounds like most of the women in your family were diagnosed postmenopausally.  That does not point as much to the BRCA 1 and 2 mutations.  And remember, mammograms miss about 25% of breast cancers.  Clinical breast exam is also very important.  If you are determined to be at high risk, the ACS is now suggesting MRI as well.
Posts.Title: Family history - need advice

Posts.Content: I agree with the poster--please try to find a breast surgeon.  They will have had more experience with something like inflammatory.  A skin biopsy will tell them more.
Posts.Title: Hello..I have a few questions...

Posts.Content: A GOOD physician would never be offended by the request of a second opinion.  It should be standard practice for all breast cancer issues.  Pathology is sometimes as much art as science and opinions can vary regarding the same sample.
Posts.Title: pathology reports and doctors

Posts.Content: Isn't she being treated with radiation?  It doesn't make a lot of sense to put her through reconstructive surgery with all this other stuff going on.  What does the plastic surgeon say?
Posts.Title: Reconstraction surgery

Posts.Content: The surgeon should be able to recommend another surgeon who can see you more quickly.  And you should tell this surgeon about the difficulty with the scheduling--the nurse may need a little chat about IBC.  The ideal person to see would be a breast surgeon, not a general surgeon.  A breast surgeon will expedite the pathology so you know what you are dealing with.  Are you near a city or university medical center with an oncology center?  That's where you need to be.  MD Anderson has recently started an IBC specialty section.  And the standard treatment for IBC is, indeed, chemotherapy first.  Let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: It's not a sign that your tumor is growing.  It could be nerves, though.  I often feel very hungry when I'm stressed but I don't feel like eating.  It is hard to wait for all this; everyone who has been through it will tell you that.  Let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Hungery sign Cancer is growing?

Posts.Content: She shouldn't need further treatment.  At her age a breast cancer would most likely be growing very slowly.  A modified radical mastectomy will take care of most of the area where there might be a local recurrence. I agree that the dementia or some other health problem will become more of a factor soon.  My grandmother and her sister both developed breast cancer while they were in nursing homes.  They got mastectomies and ended up dying of heart failure a few years later.
Posts.Title: breast cancer in my 88 yr. old mother

Posts.Content: Please make an appointment to be seen by a doctor.  It's not a medical emergency so don't go to the ER--it will cost you a fortune.  But it should be checked out.  If you can't afford it, most states have a healthy woman partnership that can get you in for mammography and ultrasound.
Posts.Title: BLEEDING FROM THE BREASTS

Posts.Content: The two procedures are equal in terms of mortality but not recurrence.  Many women who have lumpectomy and radiation have local recurrences which then require mastectomy.  Just something to keep in mind.  She should ask her surgeon about the rate of recurrence he or she is seeing with lumpectomy and radiation.  Mastectomy is more surgery but less time out of your life.  Lumpectomy is less surgery but a whole lot of radiation.
Posts.Title: Lumpectamy or Mastectomy? HELP!

Posts.Content: If you google "avemar" you will see some research regarding it.  It's not a treatment for cancer--it's a "nutriment" made of wheat grass.  Read the side effects and drug interactions and recommendations.
Posts.Title: avemar

Posts.Content: You need to call Kaiser and go up the chain with them til somebody listens to your story.  They are supposed to pay for things like second opinions.  I don't know where you live, but most states have a state insurance department and an attorney general's health care complaint line.  Call them too.  It would be much more worthwhile than a website.  Your mom should ask for all her records from this doctor--they may charge you a copying fee but get the records.  They also need to tell her exact diagnosis.  It sounds more like she has inflammatory breast cancer--it often goes to the brain.  The HER2NEU status would be important too. There are new treatments for cancers with that characteristic. I'm sorry you both are being put through this.  It is absolutely wrong.
Posts.Title: Whats next

Posts.Content: Anita, You also might want to ask about how much benefit Tamoxifen is to you.  If you can switch to another hormonal therapy or stop the Tamoxifen that might help.  There are some women for whom Tamoxifen doesn't work--a test is being developed that will tell who those women are but I don't know that it's available yet. All these non-chemo treatments are great but sometimes the trade-off isn't enough--the suffering vs. a possible recurrence.  There is a test for likelihood of recurrence--ask your oncologist.
Posts.Title: going back to work

Posts.Content: Anita, You also might want to ask about how much benefit Tamoxifen is to you.  If you can switch to another hormonal therapy or stop the Tamoxifen that might help.  There are some women for whom Tamoxifen doesn't work--a test is being developed that will tell who those women are but I don't know that it's available yet. All these non-chemo treatments are great but sometimes the trade-off isn't enough--the suffering vs. a possible recurrence.  There is a test for likelihood of recurrence--ask your oncologist.
Posts.Title: going back to work

Posts.Content: Ask the primary care physician about a breast surgeon in your area.  They do lots of these kinds of surgery and are a better idea than a general surgeon, if one is available.
Posts.Title: dr. recommendations

Posts.Content: Has she tried a second opinion with another oncologist, possibly at a major cancer center?  If you are going to help her with alternative therapies, please seek out someone who is well-trained.  Just buying this stuff yourself and trying to figure out what to do is going to be very frustrating and expensive for both of you.  Which chemotherapies did she try that she didn't tolerate?  There are many.
Posts.Title: Altenative therapies

Posts.Content: What did the radiology report say?  It would have had a BIRAD rating--it would indicate what type and how often follow up should be.  I personally wouldn't wait.  What did they say they found?  Calcifications?  A mass?  A cyst?  I wouldn't wait 9 months for follow up of a suspicious mammogram.
Posts.Title: Should I wait?

Posts.Content: All women should get second opinions regarding breast cancer.  Usually Herceptin comes after standard treatment with other chemotherapies such as Adriamycin, Cytoxan and taxol.  You can't give these drugs to yourself and since Herceptin costs about $40,000 a pop, you probably wouldn't want to try to buy it in Mexico.  There are other factors besides HER2NEU status--ER, PR status help determine treatment as well.  Take a look at nccn.org.  There are some decision trees there about diagnosis and treatment.  This can be more aggressive and I do know a mother and daughter who both had HER2+ cancers.  The daughter didn't do genetic testing--just having it tells her that her sisters are at high risk too.
Posts.Title: HER2-NU

Posts.Content: It is really rare.  Mastectomy and radiation are treatments so she is having something done for her.  All types of breast cancer are a really hot topic right now for research.  But I'm sure you understand the sense of directing the most funds to the most common types.  Clear cell cancers occur in other parts of the body as well--perhaps they are related.  Google "clear cell breast cancer" and see what you get.  I got a couple of research articles.
Posts.Title: clear cell

Posts.Content: You should consider a second opinion and possibly a clinical trial.  There are some new treatments for your mom--it can be treated like a chronic illness rather than a terminal one.  Your mom's oncologist should encourage a second opinion.
Posts.Title: its back

Posts.Content: Those are very common side effects of chemotherapy.  She needs to call her oncology nurse and ask them for some help with that.  There are some things that can be done.  Did they give her any written material about chemotherapy side effects?  They should have.  And she would want to avoid spicy foods or foods that might irritate her mouth further, like alcohol or very hot (in temperature) things.
Posts.Title: side effects?

Posts.Content: try rare-cancer.org they have message boards. also, breastcancer.org is a great site for info and they have message boards as well.
Posts.Title: adenoid cystic breast cancer
